llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: "If a dead person is in his house, he does not leave through the entrance of his anteroom." Rabbi Yehuda says: "If he wants to leave after the bed, he may leave, as we found with David who left after the bed of Abner, as it is stated: 'And King David walked behind the bier.'" They said to him: "It was only done to appease the people." And when they bury him, all the people are seated on the ground, and he is seated on a stool.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: מָקוֹם שֶׁנָּהֲגוּ נָשִׁים לָצֵאת אַחַר הַמִּיטָּה – יוֹצְאוֹת, לִפְנֵי הַמִּיטָּה – יוֹצְאוֹת. רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: לְעוֹלָם נָשִׁים לִפְנֵי הַמִּיטָּה יוֹצְאוֹת, שֶׁכֵּן מָצִינוּ בְּדָוִד שֶׁיָּצָא אַחַר מִיטָּתוֹ שֶׁל אַבְנֵר, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְהַמֶּלֶךְ דָּוִד הֹלֵךְ אַחַר הַמִּטָּה״.
human_translation: The Sages taught a place where women were accustomed to follow the bier, they would follow in front of the bier, they would go Rabbi Yehuda says: Women always go in front of the bier, as that is what we found with regard to David, who followed the bier of Abner, as it is stated: “And King David followed the bier,”
llm_translation: The Sages taught: In a place where women customarily go out after the bed - they should go out, in front of the bed - they should go out. Rabbi Yehuda says: Women should always go out in front of the bed, as we find with David who went out after the bed of Abner, as it is stated: "And King David went out after the bed."

hebrew_text: אָמְרוּ לוֹ: לֹא הָיָה הַדָּבָר אֶלָּא לְפַיֵּיס אֶת הָעָם, וְנִתְפַּיְּיסוּ. שֶׁהָיָה דָּוִד יוֹצֵא מִבֵּין הָאֲנָשִׁים וְנִכְנָס לְבֵין הַנָּשִׁים, וְיוֹצֵא מִבֵּין הַנָּשִׁים וְנִכְנָס לְבֵין הָאֲנָשִׁים, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וַיֵּדְעוּ כׇל הָעָם וְכׇל יִשְׂרָאֵל כִּי לֹא הָיְתָה מֵהַמֶּלֶךְ לְהָמִית אֶת אַבְנֵר״.
human_translation: said to him: The matter was only to appease the people, and they were appeased. As David would go out from among the men and go in among the women, and went out from among the women and went in among the men, as it is stated: “So all the people and all Israel understood that it was not from the king to slay Abner,
llm_translation: They said to him: The matter was only to appease the people, and they were appeased. For David would go out among the men and enter among the women, and go out among the women and enter among the men, as it is stated: "And all the people and all Israel understood that it was not from the king to kill Avner."

hebrew_text: דָּרֵשׁ רָבָא, מַאי דִּכְתִיב: ״וַיָּבֹא כׇל הָעָם לְהַבְרוֹת אֶת דָּוִד״? כְּתִיב ״לְהַכְרוֹת״, וְקָרֵינַן ״לְהַבְרוֹת״. בַּתְּחִלָּה לְהַכְרוֹתוֹ, וּלְבַסּוֹף לְהַבְרוֹתוֹ.
human_translation: Rava interpreted homiletically: What which is written: “And all the people came to comfort David” It is written: “To destroy [ lehakhrot ],” and we read: “To comfort [ lehavrot ],” in the beginning to destroy him, and ultimately, to comfort him.
llm_translation: Rava expounded, what is the meaning of what is written: "And all the people came to cause David to eat bread"? It is written "to recognize," and we read "to cause to eat." Initially to recognize him, and ultimately to cause him to eat.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר רַב: מִפְּנֵי מָה נֶעֱנַשׁ אַבְנֵר? מִפְּנֵי שֶׁהָיָה לוֹ לְמַחוֹת בְּשָׁאוּל וְלֹא מִיחָה. רַבִּי יִצְחָק אָמַר: מִיחָה וְלֹא נַעֲנָה. וּשְׁנֵיהֶן מִקְרָא אֶחָד דָּרְשׁוּ: ״וַיְקֹנֵן הַמֶּלֶךְ אֶל אַבְנֵר וַיֹּאמַר הַכְּמוֹת נָבָל יָמוּת אַבְנֵר יָדֶיךָ לֹא אֲסֻרוֹת וְרַגְלֶיךָ לֹא לִנְחֻשְׁתַּיִם הֻגָּשׁוּ״.
human_translation: Rav Yehuda says Rav says: For what was Abner punished because he should have protested to Saul but he did not protest. Rabbi Yitzḥak says: He did protest, but he was not answered. And both of interpreted one verse: “And the king lamented for Abner, and said: Should Abner die as a churl dies? Your hands were not bound, nor your feet put into fetters;
llm_translation: Rav Yehudah said in the name of Rav: Why was Avner punished? Because he had the opportunity to strike Saul and did not do so. Rabbi Yitzchak said: He struck but did not answer. And both of them expounded the same verse: "And the king said to Avner, 'As Nabal died, so shall Avner die. Your hands were not bound, and your feet were not put into fetters.'"

hebrew_text: מַאן דְּאָמַר לָא מִיחָה, הָכִי קָאָמַר: ״יָדֶיךָ לֹא אֲסֻרוֹת וְרַגְלֶיךָ לֹא לִנְחֻשְׁתַּיִם הוּגָּשׁוּ״, מַאי טַעְמָא לָא מַחֵית? ״כִּנְפוֹל לִפְנֵי בְנֵי עַוְלָה נָפָלְתָּ״. וּמַאן דְּאָמַר מִיחָה וְלֹא נַעֲנָה, אַתְמוֹהֵי מַתְמַהּ: ״הַכְּמוֹת נָבָל יָמוּת״? ״יָדֶיךָ לֹא אֲסוּרוֹת וְרַגְלֶיךָ לֹא לִנְחֻשְׁתַּיִם״, מִכְּדֵי מַחוֹיֵי מַחֵית, מַאי טַעְמָא ״כִּנְפוֹל לִפְנֵי בְנֵי עַוְלָה נָפָלְתָּ״?
human_translation: The one who says he did not protest this is saying: “your hands were not bound, nor your feet put into fetters,” what is the reason you did not protest “as a man falls before the children of iniquity, so did you fall.” And the one who says he protested and was not answered wondered: “Should die as a churl dies? Your hands were not bound, nor your feet put into fetters,” since you protested what is the reason “as a man falls before the children of iniquity, so did you fall”?
llm_translation: The one who says "not from a snake," this is what he is saying: "Your hands are not bound and your feet are not to be ensnared," what is the reason for not destroying? "Like a falling before the children of wickedness, you have fallen." And the one who says "a snake" and was not answered, his astonishment is astonished: "As Nabal died, so will you die." "Your hands are not bound and your feet are not to be ensnared," from the place of destroying, what is the reason "like a falling before the children of wickedness, you have fallen"?

hebrew_text: לְמַאן דְּאָמַר מִיחָה, מַאי טַעְמָא אִיעֲנַשׁ? אָמַר רַב נַחְמָן בְּרַבִּי יִצְחָק: שֶׁשִּׁהָא מַלְכוּת בֵּית דָּוִד שְׁתֵּי שָׁנִים וּמֶחֱצָה.
human_translation: According to the one who says protested, what is the reason he was punished Rav Naḥman, son of Rabbi Yitzḥak, says: because he delayed the kingdom of the house of David two and a half years,
llm_translation: To whom says "Miḥah," what reason was he punished? Said Rav Naḥman son of Rabbi Yitzḥak: Because the kingdom of the house of David was six years and a half.

hebrew_text: וּכְשֶׁמַּבְרִין אוֹתוֹ כּוּ׳. מַאי דַּרְגֵּשׁ? אָמַר עוּלָּא: עַרְסָא דְּגַדָּא. אֲמַרוּ לֵיהּ רַבָּנַן לְעוּלָּא: מִי אִיכָּא מִידֵּי דְּעַד הָאִידָּנָא לָא אוֹתְבִינֵּיהּ, וְהַשְׁתָּא מוֹתְבִינַן לֵיהּ?
human_translation: And when they comfort What a dargash ? Ulla says: A bed of fortune, The Sages said to Ulla: Is there anything until now we did not authorize one to sit but now, we seat him
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And when they bring him in, so and so. What is the meaning of "he feels"? Ulla said: The handle of a fish. The Rabbis said to Ulla: Is there anyone who, until now, did not understand it, and now understands it?

hebrew_text: מַתְקֵיף לַהּ רָבָא: מַאי קוּשְׁיָא? דִּילְמָא מִידֵּי דְּהָוֵה אַאֲכִילָה וּשְׁתִיָּה, דְּעַד הָאִידָּנָא לָא אֹכְילִנֵּיהּ וְלָא אַשְׁקִינֵּיהּ, הַשְׁתָּא קָא מוֹכְלִינַן לֵיהּ וְקָא מַשְׁקִינַן לֵיהּ. אֶלָּא אִי קַשְׁיָא, הָא קַשְׁיָא: דַּרְגֵּשׁ אֵינוֹ צָרִיךְ לִכְפּוֹתוֹ, אֶלָּא זוֹקְפוֹ. וְאִי סָלְקָא דַעְתָּךְ עַרְסָא דְּגַדָּא, אַמַּאי אֵינוֹ צָרִיךְ לִכְפּוֹתוֹ? וְהָתַנְיָא: הַכּוֹפֶה אֶת מִטָּתוֹ, לֹא מִטָּתוֹ בִּלְבַד הוּא כּוֹפֶה, אֶלָּא כׇּל מִטּוֹת שֶׁיֵּשׁ לוֹ בְּתוֹךְ בֵּיתוֹ הוּא כּוֹפֶה.
human_translation: Rava objects to this What is the difficulty Perhaps just as it is with eating and drinking. As until now, we did not feed him nor give him drink, now, we feed him and give him drink, Rather, if is difficult, this is difficult, a dargash , is not required to overturn it Rather, he stands it up And if it enters your mind a bed of fortune, why is he not required to overturn it? But isn’t it taught one who overturns his bed not only does he overturn his bed, but rather he overturns all the beds he has in his house?
llm_translation: Rava objects to this: What is the difficulty? Perhaps since it was from the time that it was designated for eating and drinking, until now we have not eaten it and have not drunk it, now we are eating it and drinking it. Rather, if it is difficult, this is the difficulty: One does not need to press down the mattress, but rather to lift it. And if it enters your mind to turn over a clod of earth, why does one not need to press it down? And it was taught: One who strikes his bed, he is not only striking his bed, but he is striking all the beds that are within his house.

hebrew_text: מַאי קוּשְׁיָא? דִּילְמָא מִידֵּי דְּהָוֵה אַמִּטָּה מְיוּחֶדֶת לְכֵלִים, דְּקָתָנֵי: אִם הָיְתָה מְיוּחֶדֶת לְכֵלִים – אֵינוֹ צָרִיךְ לִכְפּוֹתָהּ. אֶלָּא, אִי קַשְׁיָא – הָא קַשְׁיָא: רַבָּן שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן גַּמְלִיאֵל אוֹמֵר: דַּרְגֵּשׁ – מַתִּיר קַרְבִּיטִין וְהוּא נוֹפֵל מֵאֵילָיו. וְאִי סָלְקָא דַעְתָּךְ עַרְסָא דְגַדָּא, קַרְבִּיטִין מִי אִית לֵיהּ?
human_translation: What is the difficulty Perhaps just as it is with a bed designated for garments, as it is taught If it was designated for garments he is not required to overturn it. Rather, if is difficult, this is difficult, Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: a dargash . loosens the straps [ karvitin ] and it falls on its own. And if it enters your mind a bed of fortune, does have straps?
llm_translation: What is the difficulty? Perhaps because since it was designated for vessels, as it teaches: If it was designated for vessels - there is no need to nullify it. Rather, if there is a difficulty - here is the difficulty: Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: A beam that is dislodged permits the pegs, and it falls from its place. And if you think it is a fishhook of a fish, does it have pegs?

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא, כִּי אֲתָא רָבִין אֲמַר: אֲמַר לִי הַהוּא מֵרַבָּנַן, וְרַב תַּחְלִיפָא שְׁמֵיהּ, דַּהֲוָה שְׁכִיחַ בְּשׁוּקָא דְּגִילְדָּאֵי, וַאֲמַר לֵיהּ: מַאי דַּרְגֵּשׁ? עַרְסָא דְּצַלָּא. אָמַר רַבִּי יִרְמְיָה אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: דַּרְגֵּשׁ —
human_translation: Rather, when Ravin came he said: One of the Sages said to me, and Rav Taḥlifa his name, that he was often in the market of the leather workers, and he said to him: What dargash ? A leather bed. Rabbi Yirmeya says Rabbi Yoḥanan says: A dargash
llm_translation: Rather, when Ravin came, he said: That certain one said to me from the Sages, and Rav Tachlifa is his name, who was often in the market of Gildai, and he said to him: What is the meaning of "dargesh"? A bolt of shade. Rabbi Yirmeya said in the name of Rabbi Yochanan: "Dargesh" —

hebrew_text: סֵירוּגוֹ מִתּוֹכוֹ, מִטָּה – סֵירוּגָהּ מֵעַל גַּבָּהּ.
human_translation: its weaving on its inside, a bed its weaving on its outside,
llm_translation: Weave from within, below - its weaving from above.

hebrew_text: מֵיתִיבִי: כְּלֵי עֵץ, מֵאֵימָתַי מְקַבְּלִין טוּמְאָה? הַמִּטָּה וְהָעֲרִיסָה – מִשֶּׁיְּשׁוּפֵם בְּעוֹר הַדָּג. וְאִי מִטָּה מְסוֹרֶגֶת הִיא מֵעַל גַּבָּהּ, לְמָה לִי שִׁיפַת עוֹר הַדָּג? אֶלָּא, הָא וְהָא מִתּוֹכוֹ: מִטָּה – אַעוֹלֵי וְאַפּוֹקֵי בְּבִזְיוֹנֵי, דַּרְגֵּשׁ – אַעוֹלֵי וְאַפּוֹקֵי בְּאַבְקָתָא.
human_translation: raises an objection From when wooden vessels susceptible to impurity? a bed or a crib, once they are rubbed with fish skin, And if a bed is woven on its back side, why do I rubbing with fish skin? Rather, this and that, on its inside, a bed, go in and out of holes a dargash , they go in and out of loops.
llm_translation: Challenger: Wooden vessels, from when do they receive impurity? A bed and a mat - from when they are rubbed with the skin of a fish. And if a bed is woven, why do I need the rubbing of the skin of a fish? Rather, this and that from within: a bed - I will bring up and take out with disgrace, a mat - I will bring up and take out with dust.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי יַעֲקֹב: אָמַר רַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בֶּן לֵוִי: הֲלָכָה כְּרַבָּן שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן גַּמְלִיאֵל. אָמַר רַבִּי יַעֲקֹב בַּר אַמֵּי: מִטָּה שֶׁנַּקְלִיטֶיהָ יוֹצְאִין – זוֹקְפָהּ, וְדַיּוֹ.
human_translation: Rabbi Ya’akov says Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi says: halakha in accordance with Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel Rabbi Ya’akov bar Ami says: a bed whose posts [ naklitim ] extend, stands it up and is sufficient.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yaakov said: Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said: The halacha is in accordance with Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel. Rabbi Yaakov bar Ami said: From a bed that its legs have been removed - it is considered as dismantled, and it is sufficient.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ וּמוֹצִיא לְמִלְחֶמֶת הָרְשׁוּת עַל פִּי בֵּית דִּין שֶׁל שִׁבְעִים וְאֶחָד, וּפוֹרֵץ לַעֲשׂוֹת לוֹ דֶּרֶךְ וְאֵין מְמַחֶה בְּיָדוֹ. דֶּרֶךְ הַמֶּלֶךְ אֵין לוֹ שִׁיעוּר, וְכׇל הָעָם בּוֹזְזִין וְנוֹתְנִין לוֹ, וְהוּא נוֹטֵל חֵלֶק בָּרֹאשׁ.
human_translation: And brings out for an optional war, on the basis of a court of seventy-one, and breaches to create a pathway for himself and no one can protest his power. The pathway of the king has no measure, And all the people take spoils and give to him, and he takes the first portion
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: "And one who goes out to wage a discretionary war according to the ruling of the Sanhedrin of seventy-one, and he breaks through to make a path for himself, and no one hinders him. The king's path has no measure, and all the people plunder and give to him, and he takes a portion at the head."

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ תְּנֵינָא חֲדָא זִימְנָא: אֵין מוֹצִיאִין לְמִלְחֶמֶת הָרְשׁוּת אֶלָּא עַל פִּי בֵּית דִּין שֶׁל שִׁבְעִים וְאֶחָד. אַיְּידֵי דִּתְנָא כֹּל מִילֵּי דְּמֶלֶךְ, תְּנָא נָמֵי מוֹצִיאִין לְמִלְחֶמֶת הָרְשׁוּת.
human_translation: We learn another occasion bring out to an optional war only on the basis of a court of seventy-one Since taught all matters to the king, he also taught bringing out to an optional war,
llm_translation: The Talmudic text: "Gemara: We learned in one place: One may not go out to wage a discretionary war except by the authority of the court of seventy-one. The reason is that a Baraita taught: With regard to all matters of the king, the Mishna similarly states: One may go out to wage a discretionary war." I hope this translation is helpful to you.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר שְׁמוּאֵל: כׇּל הָאָמוּר בְּפָרָשַׁת מֶלֶךְ – מֶלֶךְ מוּתָּר בּוֹ. רַב אָמַר: לֹא נֶאֶמְרָה פָּרָשָׁה זוֹ אֶלָּא לְאַיֵּים עֲלֵיהֶם, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״שׂוֹם תָּשִׂים עָלֶיךָ מֶלֶךְ״ – שֶׁתְּהֵא אֵימָתוֹ עָלֶיךָ.
human_translation: Rav Yehuda says Shmuel says: all that are stated in the passage about king is permitted a king to them. Rav says: This passage was stated only to threaten as it is stated: “You shall set a king over you” that his fear should be upon you.
llm_translation: Rav Yehudah said in the name of Shmuel: Anything stated in the portion concerning a king - a king is permitted in it. Rav said: This portion was only said to warn them, as it is stated: "You shall surely set a king over you" - that his fear should be upon you.

hebrew_text: כְּתַנָּאֵי, רַבִּי יוֹסֵי אוֹמֵר: כׇּל הָאָמוּר בְּפָרָשַׁת מֶלֶךְ – מֶלֶךְ מוּתָּר בּוֹ. רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: לֹא נֶאֶמְרָה פָּרָשָׁה זוֹ אֶלָּא כְּדֵי לְאַיֵּים עֲלֵיהֶם, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״שׂוֹם תָּשִׂים עָלֶיךָ מֶלֶךְ״ – שֶׁתְּהֵא אֵימָתוֹ עָלֶיךָ.
human_translation: parallel to tanna’im , Rabbi Yosei says: all that are stated in the passage about king, is permitted a king to them. Rabbi Yehuda says: This passage was stated only to threaten as it is stated: “You shall set a king over you” that his fear should be upon you.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: As the Tannaim taught, Rabbi Yosei says: Anything stated in the portion of a king - the king is permitted in it. Rabbi Yehuda says: This portion was only stated in order to warn them, as it is said: "You shall surely set a king over you" - that his fear should be upon you.

hebrew_text: וְכֵן הָיָה רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: שָׁלֹשׁ מִצְוֹת נִצְטַוּוּ יִשְׂרָאֵל בִּכְנִיסָתָן לָאָרֶץ – לְהַעֲמִיד לָהֶם מֶלֶךְ, וּלְהַכְרִית זַרְעוֹ שֶׁל עֲמָלֵק, וְלִבְנוֹת לָהֶם בֵּית הַבְּחִירָה.
human_translation: And so would Rabbi Yehuda say: Three mitzvot were commanded Jewish people upon their entrance into Eretz to establish a king for themselves and to cut off the seed of Amalek and to build the Chosen House,
llm_translation: And so Rabbi Yehudah would say: Three commandments were commanded to the children of Israel upon their entry into the land - to appoint for themselves a king, to obliterate the seed of Amalek, and to build for themselves the chosen House.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי נְהוֹרַאי אוֹמֵר: לֹא נֶאֶמְרָה פָּרָשָׁה זוֹ אֶלָּא כְּנֶגֶד תַּרְעוֹמְתָּן, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְאָמַרְתָּ אָשִׂימָה עָלַי מֶלֶךְ וְגוֹ׳״.
human_translation: Rabbi Nehorai says: This passage was stated only in response to complaint, as it is stated: and shall say: I will set a king over me,
llm_translation: Rabbi Nehorai says: This portion was only said corresponding to their arrogance, as it is stated: "And you will say, 'I will set a king over me...'"

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא, רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר אוֹמֵר: זְקֵנִים שֶׁבַּדּוֹר כַּהוֹגֶן שָׁאֲלוּ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״תְּנָה לָנוּ מֶלֶךְ לְשׇׁפְטֵנוּ״. אֲבָל עַמֵּי הָאָרֶץ שֶׁבָּהֶן קִלְקְלוּ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְהָיִינוּ גַם אֲנַחְנוּ כְּכׇל הַגּוֹיִם וּשְׁפָטָנוּ מַלְכֵּנוּ וְיָצָא לְפָנֵינוּ״.
human_translation: It is taught Rabbi Eliezer says: The elders of generation asked appropriately, as it is stated: “Give us a king to judge us” But the ignoramuses among them ruined as it is stated: that we also may be like all the nations, and that our king may judge us, and emerge before us,
llm_translation: It was taught: Rabbi Eliezer says: The elders of the generation who are wise asked, as it is stated: "Appoint for us a king to judge us." But the common people who are corrupt asked, as it is stated: "And we will be like all the nations, and our king will judge us and go out before us."

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא, רַבִּי יוֹסֵי אוֹמֵר: שָׁלֹשׁ מִצְוֹת נִצְטַוּוּ יִשְׂרָאֵל בִּכְנִיסָתָן לָאָרֶץ – לְהַעֲמִיד לָהֶם מֶלֶךְ, וּלְהַכְרִית זַרְעוֹ שֶׁל עֲמָלֵק, וְלִבְנוֹת לָהֶם בֵּית הַבְּחִירָה. וְאֵינִי יוֹדֵעַ אֵיזֶה מֵהֶן תְּחִילָּה.
human_translation: It is taught Rabbi Yosei says: Three mitzvot were commanded Jewish people upon their entrance into Eretz To establish a king for themselves, and to cut off the seed of Amalek and to build for themselves the Chosen House But I do not know which one first.
llm_translation: It was taught: Rabbi Yosei says: Three commandments were commanded to the Israelites upon their entry into the land - to appoint for themselves a king, to obliterate the seed of Amalek, and to build for themselves the chosen house. And I do not know which of them takes precedence.

hebrew_text: כְּשֶׁהוּא אוֹמֵר: ״כִּי יָד עַל כֵּס יָהּ מִלְחָמָה לַה׳ בַּעֲמָלֵק״, הֱוֵי אוֹמֵר: לְהַעֲמִיד לָהֶם מֶלֶךְ תְּחִילָּה. וְאֵין ״כִּסֵּא״ אֶלָּא מֶלֶךְ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וַיֵּשֶׁב שְׁלֹמֹה עַל כִּסֵּא ה׳ לְמֶלֶךְ״.
human_translation: When states: “The hand upon the throne [ kes ] of the Lord: The Lord will have war with Amalek you must say to establish a king for themselves first, and “Throne is nothing other than a king, as it is stated: “Then Solomon sat on the throne [ kisei ] of the Lord as king”
llm_translation: When he says: "For there shall be a hand upon the throne of the Lord, that there shall be war with Amalek," one should say: first establish a king for them. And "throne" is nothing but a king, as it is said: "And Solomon sat on the throne of the Lord as king."

hebrew_text: וַעֲדַיִין אֵינִי יוֹדֵעַ אִם לִבְנוֹת לָהֶם בֵּית הַבְּחִירָה תְּחִלָּה, אוֹ לְהַכְרִית זַרְעוֹ שֶׁל עֲמָלֵק תְּחִלָּה. כְּשֶׁהוּא אוֹמֵר: ״וְהֵנִיחַ לָכֶם מִכׇּל אוֹיְבֵיכֶם וְגוֹ׳ וְהָיָה הַמָּקוֹם אֲשֶׁר יִבְחַר ה׳ וְגוֹ׳״, הֱוֵי אוֹמֵר: לְהַכְרִית זַרְעוֹ שֶׁל עֲמָלֵק תְּחִלָּה.
human_translation: And still I do not know whether building them the Chosen House is first, or cutting off the seed of Amalek is first, When states: “And He will give you rest from all your enemies it shall come to pass that the place that the Lord shall choose you must say to cut off the seed of Amalek first.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And still I do not know if to build for them the chosen house first, or to cut off the seed of Amalek first. When it says, "And He will give you rest from all your enemies, and the place which the Lord your God shall choose, and so on," one should say: to cut off the seed of Amalek first.

hebrew_text: וְכֵן בְּדָוִד הוּא אוֹמֵר: ״וַיְהִי כִּי יָשַׁב הַמֶּלֶךְ דָּוִד בְּבֵיתוֹ וַה׳ הֵנִיחַ לוֹ מִסָּבִיב״, וּכְתִיב: ״וַיֹּאמֶר הַמֶּלֶךְ אֶל נָתָן הַנָּבִיא רְאֵה נָא אָנֹכִי יוֹשֵׁב בְּבֵית אֲרָזִים וְגוֹ׳״.
human_translation: And so states concerning David: “And it came to pass, when King David dwelled in his house and the Lord had given him rest round about And it is written “That the king said to Nathan the prophet: See now, I dwell in a house of cedar
llm_translation: And so too, in David, he says: "And it came to pass, when King David dwelt in his house, and the Lord had given him rest round about," and it is written: "And the king said unto Nathan the prophet, See now, I dwell in a house of cedar, and the like."

hebrew_text: אָמַר רֵישׁ לָקִישׁ: בַּתְּחִילָּה מָלַךְ שְׁלֹמֹה עַל הָעֶלְיוֹנִים, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וַיֵּשֶׁב שְׁלֹמֹה עַל כִּסֵּא ה׳״, וּלְבַסּוֹף מָלַךְ עַל הַתַּחְתּוֹנִים, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״כִּי הוּא רֹדֶה בְּכׇל עֵבֶר הַנָּהָר מִתִּפְסַח וְעַד עַזָּה״.
human_translation: Reish Lakish says: Initially, Solomon ruled over the supernal as it is stated: “Then Solomon sat on the throne of the Lord” But ultimately, he ruled over the lower as it is stated: “For he had dominion over all the region on this side of the river, from Tiphsah even to Gaza”
llm_translation: Reish Lakish said: Initially, King Solomon ruled over the upper realms, as it is stated: "And Solomon sat on the throne of the Lord" (1 Kings 10:18). And ultimately, he ruled over the lower realms, as it is stated: "For he had dominion over all the region on this side of the River, from Tiphsah even to Gaza" (1 Kings 5:4).

hebrew_text: רַב וּשְׁמוּאֵל: חַד אָמַר, ״תִּפְסַח בְּסוֹף הָעוֹלָם וְעַזָּה בְּסוֹף הָעוֹלָם״, וְחַד אָמַר, ״תִּפְסַח וְעַזָּה בַּהֲדֵי הֲדָדֵי הֲווֹ יָתְבִי״, וּכְשֵׁם שֶׁמָּלַךְ עַל תִּפְסַח וְעַל עַזָּה כָּךְ מָלַךְ עַל כׇּל הָעוֹלָם כּוּלּוֹ.
human_translation: Rav and Shmuel One says Tiphsah at the end of the world, and Gaza is at the end of the world. And one says Tiphsah and Gaza sat next to each other, and just as he ruled over Tiphsah and over Gaza, so he ruled over the whole world.
llm_translation: Rav and Shmuel: One said, "Tifsach at the end of the world and Azah at the end of the world," and one said, "Tifsach and Azah in the presence of Hadadei Havo Yatvi," and just as he ruled regarding Tifsach and Azah, so he ruled over the entire world altogether.

hebrew_text: וּלְבַסּוֹף לֹא מָלַךְ אֶלָּא עַל יִשְׂרָאֵל, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״אֲנִי קֹהֶלֶת הָיִיתִי מֶלֶךְ עַל יִשְׂרָאֵל וְגוֹ׳״. וּלְבַסּוֹף לֹא מָלַךְ אֶלָּא עַל יְרוּשָׁלַיִם, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״דִּבְרֵי קֹהֶלֶת בֶּן דָּוִד מֶלֶךְ בִּירוּשָׁלִָים״. וּלְבַסּוֹף, לֹא מָלַךְ אֶלָּא עַל מִטָּתוֹ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״הִנֵּה מִטָּתוֹ שֶׁלִּשְׁלֹמֹה וְגוֹ׳״.
human_translation: And ultimately, he ruled only over Israel, as it is stated: “I, Koheleth, have been king over Israel And ultimately, he ruled over only Jerusalem, as it is stated: “The words of Koheleth, the son of David, king in Jerusalem” And ultimately, he ruled over only his bed, as it is stated: “Behold, it is the bed of Solomon;
llm_translation: At the end, he only ruled over Israel, as it is stated: "I, Kohelet, was king over Israel, etc." And at the end, he only ruled over Jerusalem, as it is stated: "The words of Kohelet, son of David, king in Jerusalem." And at the end, he only ruled over his own bed, as it is stated: "Behold, it is the bed of Shlomo, etc."

hebrew_text: וּלְבַסּוֹף לֹא מָלַךְ אֶלָּא עַל מַקְלוֹ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״זֶה הָיָה חֶלְקִי מִכׇּל עֲמָלִי״. רַב וּשְׁמוּאֵל: חַד אָמַר מַקְלוֹ, וְחַד אָמַר גּוּנְדּוֹ.
human_translation: And ultimately, he ruled over only his staff, as it is stated: “And this was my portion from all of my labor” Rav and Shmuel One says his staff, and one says his cloak.
llm_translation: At the end, he only ruled with his staff, as it is stated: "This was my portion from all my toil." Rav and Shmuel: one said his staff, and one said his gundu.

hebrew_text: הֲדַר אוֹ לָא הֲדַר? רַב וּשְׁמוּאֵל: חַד אָמַר הֲדַר, וְחַד אָמַר לָא הֲדַר. מַאן דְּאָמַר לָא הֲדַר – מֶלֶךְ וְהֶדְיוֹט, וּמַאן דְּאָמַר הֲדַר – מֶלֶךְ וְהֶדְיוֹט וָמֶלֶךְ.
human_translation: Did he return or did he not return? Rav and Shmuel One says he returned, and one says he did not return. The one who says he did not return a king and an ordinary [ hedyot ] and the one who says he returned a king and an ordinary and a king.
llm_translation: The Talmudic text: "Hadar o la hadar? Rav u'Shmuel: Chad amar hadar, v'chad amar la hadar. Man de'amar la hadar - melech v'hedyot, u'man de'amar hadar - melech v'hedyot v'melech." English translation: "Did he adorn or did he not adorn? Rav and Shmuel: One said he adorned, and one said he did not adorn. The one who said he did not adorn - a king and a commoner, and the one who said he adorned - a king and a commoner and a king."

hebrew_text: פּוֹרֵץ לַעֲשׂוֹת לוֹ דֶּרֶךְ. תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: אוֹצְרוֹת מְלָכִים – לַמֶּלֶךְ, וּשְׁאָר בִּיזָּה שֶׁבּוֹזְזִין – מֶחֱצָה לַמֶּלֶךְ וּמֶחֱצָה לָעָם. אֲמַר לֵיהּ אַבָּיֵי לְרַב דִּימִי, וְאָמְרִי לַהּ לְרַב אַחָא: בִּשְׁלָמָא אוֹצְרוֹת מְלָכִים לַמֶּלֶךְ – אוֹרְחָא דְמִלְּתָא, אֶלָּא שְׁאָר בִּיזָּה שֶׁבּוֹזְזִין מֶחֱצָה לַמֶּלֶךְ וּמֶחֱצָה לָעָם – מְנָלַן? דִּכְתִיב:
human_translation: breaches to create a pathway for himself. The Sages taught Treasures of kings to the king, and the rest of the spoils that are taken half for the king and half for the people. Abaye said to Rav Dimi, and some say to Rav Aḥa: Granted, treasures of kings to the king. the typical manner but the rest of the spoils that are taken half for the king and half for the people, from where do we as it is written:
llm_translation: Breaking to do for him a way. The Rabbis taught: Treasures of kings - for the king, and the rest of the spoils that are plundered - half for the king and half for the people. Abaye said to Rav Dimi, and some say to Rav Acha: Regarding treasures of kings for the king - it is the way of the matter, but the rest of the spoils that are plundered, half for the king and half for the people - from where? As it is written:

hebrew_text: ״וַיִּמְשְׁחוּ לַה׳ לְנָגִיד וּלְצָדוֹק״, מַקִּישׁ נָגִיד לְצָדוֹק: מָה צָדוֹק – מֶחֱצָה לוֹ וּמֶחֱצָה לְאֶחָיו, אַף נָגִיד – מֶחֱצָה לוֹ וּמֶחֱצָה לְאֶחָיו.
human_translation: and anointed him unto the Lord to be leader, and Tzadok compares a leader, to Tzadok, Just as Tzadok, half for him, and half for his brothers, so too the leader, half for him and half for his brothers,
llm_translation: "And they anointed to the Lord for a leader and for Zadok," comparing a leader to Zadok: Just as Zadok - half for himself and half for his brothers, so too a leader - half for himself and half for his brothers."

hebrew_text: וְצָדוֹק גּוּפֵיהּ מְנָלַן? דְּתַנְיָא: רַבִּי אוֹמֵר: ״וְהָיְתָה לְאַהֲרֹן וּלְבָנָיו״ – מֶחֱצָה לְאַהֲרֹן וּמֶחֱצָה לְבָנָיו.
human_translation: And Tzadok himself, from where do we As it is taught Rabbi says: “And it shall be for Aaron and his sons, Half for Aaron and half for his sons.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "And where is the body of Zadok? For it was taught: Rabbi says: 'And it shall be for Aaron and his sons' - half for Aaron and half for his sons."

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ ״לֹא יַרְבֶּה לוֹ נָשִׁים״, אֶלָּא שְׁמֹנֶה עֶשְׂרֵה. רַבִּי יְהוּדָה אוֹמֵר: מַרְבֶּה הוּא לוֹ, וּבִלְבַד שֶׁלֹּא יְהוּ מְסִירוֹת אֶת לִבּוֹ. רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן אוֹמֵר: אֲפִילּוּ אַחַת וּמְסִירָה אֶת לִבּוֹ – הֲרֵי זֶה לֹא יִשָּׂאֶנָּה. אִם כֵּן, לָמָּה נֶאֱמַר ״לֹא יַרְבֶּה לוֹ נָשִׁים״? דַּאֲפִילּוּ כַּאֲבִיגַיִל.
human_translation: “shall not add many wives for himself” but eighteen. Rabbi Yehuda says: He add many for himself, provided that they are not turn his heart Rabbi Shimon says: Even one she turns his heart away, he should not marry her. If so, why is it stated: “He shall not add many wives for himself”? that even like Abigail,
llm_translation: Mishnah: "He shall not multiply wives for himself," except eighteen. Rabbi Yehudah says: He may multiply for himself, as long as they do not turn his heart away. Rabbi Shimon says: Even one, if she turns his heart away - he shall not marry her. If so, why is it stated, "He shall not multiply wives for himself"? Even like Abigail.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ לְמֵימְרָא דְּרַבִּי יְהוּדָה דָּרֵישׁ טַעְמָא דִּקְרָא, וְרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן לָא דָּרֵישׁ טַעְמָא דִּקְרָא? וְהָא אִיפְּכָא שָׁמְעִינַן לְהוּ!
human_translation: Is this to say that Rabbi Yehuda interprets the rationale in the verse and Rabbi Shimon does not interpret the rationale in the verse? But didn’t we hear them opposite
llm_translation: Gemara: Regarding the statement of Rabbi Yehuda who expounds the reason of the verse, and Rabbi Shimon who does not expound the reason of the verse? But we have heard the opposite!

hebrew_text: דְּתַנְיָא: אַלְמָנָה, בֵּין שֶׁהִיא עֲנִיָּה בֵּין שֶׁהִיא עֲשִׁירָה, אֵין מְמַשְׁכְּנִין אוֹתָהּ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״לֹא תַחֲבֹל בֶּגֶד אַלְמָנָה״ – דִּבְרֵי רַבִּי יְהוּדָה. רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן אוֹמֵר: עֲשִׁירָה – מְמַשְׁכְּנִין אוֹתָהּ, עֲנִיָּיה – אֵין מְמַשְׁכְּנִין אוֹתָהּ, וְאַתָּה חַיָּיב לְהַחְזִיר לָהּ, וְאַתָּה מַשִּׂיאָהּ שֵׁם רַע בִּשְׁכֵנוֹתֶיהָ.
human_translation: As it is taught a widow, whether she is poor or whether she is wealthy, one may not take collateral from her as it is stated: “You may not take the garment of a widow for a pledge” the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Shimon says: a wealthy take collateral from her. a poor one may not take collateral from her, you obligated to return to her, and you give her a bad name among her neighbors.
llm_translation: It was taught in a Baraita: A widow, whether she is poor or whether she is rich, one does not marry her off, as it is stated: "You shall not take a widow's garment as security" – the words of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Shimon says: If she is rich, one may marry her off, if she is poor, one does not marry her off, and you are obligated to return it to her, and you bring a bad name upon her in her neighbors.

hebrew_text: וְאָמְרִינַן: מַאי קָאָמַר? הָכִי קָאָמַר: מִתּוֹךְ שֶׁאַתָּה מְמַשְׁכְּנָהּ, אַתָּה חַיָּיב לְהַחֲזִיר לָהּ, וְאַתָּה מַשִּׂיאָהּ שֵׁם רַע בִּשְׁכֵנוֹתֶיהָ. אַלְמָא, רַבִּי יְהוּדָה לָא דָּרֵישׁ טַעְמָא דִּקְרָא, וְרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן דָּרֵישׁ טַעְמָא דִּקְרָא.
human_translation: And we say What is saying? This he is saying: Because you take collateral from her, you are required to return to her, and you give her a bad name among her neighbors, Evidently, Rabbi Yehuda does not interpret the rationale in the verse and Rabbi Shimon interpret the rationale in the verse.
llm_translation: And we say: What is it saying? This is what it is saying: Because you are drawing her, you are obligated to return her, and you are causing a bad name for her in her neighbors. This implies that Rabbi Yehuda does not expound the reason of the verse, and Rabbi Shimon expounds the reason of the verse.

hebrew_text: בְּעָלְמָא, רַבִּי יְהוּדָה לָא דָּרֵישׁ טַעְמָא דִּקְרָא, וְשָׁאנֵי הָכָא דִּמְפָרֵשׁ טַעְמָא דִקְרָא: מַה טַּעַם ״לֹא יַרְבֶּה לוֹ נָשִׁים״? מִשּׁוּם ״דְּלֹא יָסוּר לְבָבוֹ״.
human_translation: Generally, Rabbi Yehuda does not interpret the rationale in the verse, but it is different here, as explains the rationale in the verse: What is the reason “he shall not add many wives for himself”? because of “His heart should not turn.”
llm_translation: In the world, Rabbi Yehuda does not expound the reason of the verse, and it is different here where the reason of the verse is explained: What is the reason for "he shall not multiply wives for himself"? Because "so that his heart will not turn away."

hebrew_text: וְרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן אָמַר לָךְ: מִכְּדִי בְּעָלְמָא דָּרְשִׁינַן טַעְמָא דִּקְרָא, אִם כֵּן לִכְתּוֹב קְרָא ״לֹא יַרְבֶּה לוֹ נָשִׁים״ וְלִישְׁתּוֹק, וַאֲנָא אָמֵינָא: מָה טַעַם ״לֹא יַרְבֶּה״? מִשּׁוּם דְּ״לֹא יָסוּר״. ״לֹא יָסוּר״ לְמָה לִי? אֲפִילּוּ אַחַת וּמְסִירָה אֶת לִבּוֹ – הֲרֵי זוֹ לֹא יִשָּׂאֶנָּה. אֶלָּא מָה אֲנִי מְקַיֵּים ״לֹא יַרְבֶּה״? דַּאֲפִילּוּ כַּאֲבִיגַיִל.
human_translation: And Rabbi Shimon said to you: Since generally we interpret the rationale in the verse, if so the verse should write “He shall not add many wives for himself” and be silent. I would say, what is the reason he shall not add many so that should not turn away. why do I should not turn away”? even one she turns his heart away, he should not marry her. But how do I realize “He shall not add many that even like Abigail.
llm_translation: Rabbi Shimon said to you: Since in the world we seek the reason of the verse, if so, it should have been written in the verse "he shall not multiply wives" and be silent. But I say: What is the reason for "he shall not multiply"? Because of "he shall not turn away." "He shall not turn away," why do I need it? Even if one removes his heart – this one he shall not marry. Rather, how do I fulfill "he shall not multiply"? Like Abigail.

hebrew_text: הָנֵי שְׁמוֹנֶה עֶשְׂרֵה מְנָלַן? דִּכְתִיב: ״וַיִּוָּלְדוּ לְדָוִד בָּנִים בְּחֶבְרוֹן וַיְהִי בְכוֹרוֹ אַמְנוֹן לַאֲחִינֹעַם הַיִּזְרְעֵאלִית. וּמִשְׁנֵהוּ כִלְאָב לַאֲבִיגַיִל אֵשֶׁת נָבָל הַכַּרְמְלִי וְהַשְּׁלִישִׁי אַבְשָׁלוֹם בֶּן מַעֲכָה ... וְהָרְבִיעִי אֲדֹנִיָּה בֶן חַגִּית וְהַחֲמִישִׁי שְׁפַטְיָה בֶן אֲבִיטָל. וְהַשִּׁשִּׁי יִתְרְעָם לְעֶגְלָה אֵשֶׁת דָּוִד אֵלֶּה יֻלְּדוּ לְדָוִד בְּחֶבְרוֹן״.
human_translation: those eighteen from where do we As it is written: “And to David sons were born in Hebron; and his firstborn was Amnon, from Ahinoam the Jezreelitess; and his second, Chileab, from Abigail the wife of Nabal the Carmelite; and the third, Absalom, son of Maacah, and the fourth, Adonijah, son of Haggith; and the fifth, Shephatiah, son of Abital; and the sixth, Ithream, of Eglah, David’s wife. These were born to David in Hebron”
llm_translation: These eighteen, where are they from? As it is written: "And to David were sons born in Hebron; and his firstborn was Amnon, of Ahinoam the Jezreelitess; and the second, Chileab, of Abigail the wife of Nabal the Carmelite; and the third, Absalom the son of Maacah ... and the fourth, Adonijah the son of Haggith; and the fifth, Shephatiah the son of Abital; and the sixth, Ithream, by Eglah David's wife. These were born to David in Hebron."

hebrew_text: וְקָאָמַר לֵיהּ נָבִיא: ״אִם מְעַט, וְאֹסִיפָה לְּךָ כָּהֵנָּה וְכָהֵנָּה״. ״כָּהֵנָּה״ – שֵׁית, ״וְכָהֵנָּה״ – שֵׁית, דְּהָווּ לְהוּ תַּמְנֵי סְרֵי.
human_translation: prophet said to if that were too little, then I would add to you like these and like those” “Like these”; six. “And like those”; six, that are eighteen
llm_translation: And he said to him the prophet: "If little, and I will add to you priest and priest." "Priest" - six, "and priest" - six, for they were to him twelve princes.

hebrew_text: מַתְקֵיף לַהּ רָבִינָא: אֵימַר, ״כָּהֵנָּה״ – תַּרְתֵּי סְרֵי, ״וְכָהֵנָּה״ – עֶשְׂרִין וְאַרְבַּע.
human_translation: Ravina objects to this Say “Like these”; twelve. “And like those”; twenty-four.
llm_translation: Ravina objects to her: Say, "Kohena" - two srei, "vekohena" - twenty and four.

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא נָמֵי הָכִי: ״לֹא יַרְבֶּה לוֹ נָשִׁים״ – יוֹתֵר מֵעֶשְׂרִים וְאַרְבַּע. לְמַאן דְּדָרֵישׁ וָיו, אַרְבָּעִים וּשְׁמֹנֶה הָווּ. תַּנְיָא נָמֵי הָכִי: ״לֹא יַרְבֶּה לוֹ נָשִׁים״ – יוֹתֵר מֵאַרְבָּעִים וּשְׁמֹנֶה.
human_translation: is also taught “He shall not add many wives to himself”; more than twenty-four According to the one who interprets vav , there are forty-eight is also taught “He shall not add many wives to himself”; more than forty-eight
llm_translation: It was taught in a Baraita in the name of the following Amora: "He shall not multiply wives" - more than twenty-four. According to the one who expounds "and he shall have," they were forty-eight. It was taught in a Baraita in the name of the following Amora: "He shall not multiply wives" - more than forty-eight.

hebrew_text: וְתַנָּא דִּידַן, מַאי טַעְמֵיהּ? אָמַר רַב כָּהֲנָא: מַקִּישׁ ״כָּהֵנָּה״ בָּתְרָא לְ״כָּהֵנָּה״ קַמָּא: מָה ״כָּהֵנָּה״ קַמָּא – שֵׁית, אַף ״כָּהֵנָּה״ בָּתְרָא – שֵׁית.
human_translation: And the tanna of our what is his reason Rav Kahana says: compares the latter “Like those [ kahenna ],” to the former “Like these [ kahenna ],” just as the former “Like these,” six, so too, the latter “Like those,” six
llm_translation: Our Mishna, what is its reasoning? Rav Kahana said: It compares "kohenah" mentioned later to "kohenah" mentioned earlier: Just as "kohenah" mentioned earlier is six, so too "kohenah" mentioned later is six.

hebrew_text: וְהָא הֲוַאי מִיכַל! אָמַר רַב: עֶגְלָה זוֹ מִיכַל, וְלָמָּה נִקְרָא שְׁמָהּ עֶגְלָה? שֶׁחֲבִיבָה עָלָיו כְּעֶגְלָה. וְכֵן הוּא אוֹמֵר: ״לוּלֵי חֲרַשְׁתֶּם בְּעֶגְלָתִי וְגוֹ׳״.
human_translation: But there was Michal, Rav said: Eglah, is Michal, and why was she called Eglah because she was dear to him like a calf [ egla ], and so states “If you had not plowed with my calf
llm_translation: And this was Michal! Rav said: This calf is Michal, and why is she called by the name Eglah? Because she was as dear to him as a calf. And so it says: "If you had not plowed with my heifer..."

hebrew_text: וּמִי הֲווֹ לְמִיכַל בְּנֵי? וְהָכְתִיב: ״וּלְמִיכַל בַּת שָׁאוּל לֹא הָיָה לָהּ וָלָד עַד יוֹם מוֹתָהּ״! אָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: עַד יוֹם מוֹתָהּ לֹא הָיָה לָהּ, בְּיוֹם מוֹתָהּ הָיָה לָהּ.
human_translation: And did Michal have children? But isn’t it written: “And Michal the daughter of Saul had no child until the day of her death” Rav Ḥisda said: Until the day of her death she had no on the day of her death she had
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "And who were Michal's sons? And it is written: 'And Michal the daughter of Saul had no child until the day of her death'! Rav Ḥisda said: Until the day of her death she had none, on the day of her death she had." English translation: "And who were Michal's sons? And it is written: 'And Michal the daughter of Saul had no child until the day of her death'! Rav Ḥisda said: Until the day of her death she had none, on the day of her death she had."

hebrew_text: מִכְּדֵי, בָּנִים הֵיכָא קָא חָשֵׁיב לְהוּ? בְּחֶבְרוֹן. וְאִילּוּ מַעֲשֶׂה דְּמִיכַל בִּירוּשָׁלַיִם הֲוָה, דִּכְתִיב: ״וּמִיכַל בַּת שָׁאוּל נִשְׁקְפָה בְּעַד הַחַלּוֹן וַתֵּרֶא אֶת הַמֶּלֶךְ דָּוִד מְפַזֵּז וּמְכַרְכֵּר לִפְנֵי ה׳ וַתִּבֶז״. וְאָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה, וְאִיתֵּימָא רַב יוֹסֵף: שְׁקַלְתֵּהּ מִיכַל לְמִיטְרַפְסַהּ! אֶלָּא אֵימָא: עַד אוֹתוֹ מַעֲשֶׂה – הָיָה לָהּ, מִכָּאן וְאֵילָךְ – לֹא הָיָה לָהּ.
human_translation: Now, children where does it count them? In Hebron, But the incident with Michal, was in Jerusalem, as it is written: that Michal the daughter of Saul looked out the window and saw King David leaping and dancing before the Lord, and she despised And Rav Yehuda says, and some say Rav Yosef Michal received her punishment [ lemitarpesah ] Rather, say Until that incident, she had from that forward, she did not have
llm_translation: From where, with regard to sons, is it considered for them? In Hebron. And if the incident of Michal in Jerusalem had occurred, as it is written: "Now Michal, Saul's daughter, looked out of the window and saw King David leaping and dancing before the Lord, and she despised him." And Rav Yehudah said, and some say Rav Yosef: Michal took it to Metraphsa! Rather say: Up to that incident - she had it, from here on - she did not have it.

hebrew_text: וְהָכְתִיב: ״וַיִּקַּח דָּוִד עוֹד פִּלַגְשִׁים וְנָשִׁים בִּירוּשָׁלַיִם״? לְמַלּוֹיֵי שְׁמוֹנָה עֶשְׂרֵה. מַאי ״נָשִׁים״ וּמַאי ״פִּלַגְשִׁים״? אָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר רַב: נָשִׁים – בִּכְתוּבָּה וּבְקִידּוּשִׁין, פִּלַגְשִׁים – בְּלֹא כְּתוּבָּה וּבְלֹא קִידּוּשִׁין.
human_translation: But isn’t it written: “And David took more concubines and wives in Jerusalem to complete eighteen What “wives” and what “concubines” Rav Yehuda says Rav says: Wives a marriage contract and betrothal; concubines are without a marriage contract and without betrothal.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And it is written: "And David took more concubines and wives in Jerusalem."? For the fillers of his name eighteen. What is "wives" and what is "concubines"? Rav Yehudah said in the name of Rav: Wives - with a marriage contract and with sanctification, concubines - without a marriage contract and without sanctification.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר רַב: אַרְבַּע מֵאוֹת יְלָדִים הָיוּ לוֹ לְדָוִד, וְכוּלָּן בְּנֵי יְפַת תּוֹאַר הָיוּ, וּמְגַדְּלֵי בְלוֹרִיּוֹת הָיוּ, וְכוּלָּן יוֹשְׁבִין בִּקְרוֹנוֹת שֶׁל זָהָב, וּמְהַלְּכִין בְּרָאשֵׁי גְיָיסוֹת הָיוּ, וְהֵם הָיוּ בַּעֲלֵי אֶגְרוֹפִין שֶׁל בֵּית דָּוִד.
human_translation: Rav Yehuda says Rav says: David had four hundred children and all of them were sons of beautiful women And they grew a gentile hairstyle, and they all sat in carriages [ bikronot ] of gold. And they walked at the head of the troops, and they were the strong-arm of the house of David,
llm_translation: Rav Yehudah said in the name of Rav: David had four hundred children, and all of them were of beautiful appearance, and they were raised in cradles of gold, and they walked on the tops of the battlements, and they were owners of slings of the house of David.

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר רַב: תָּמָר בַּת יְפַת תּוֹאַר הָיְתָה, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְעַתָּה דַּבֶּר נָא אֶל הַמֶּלֶךְ כִּי לֹא יִמְנָעֵנִי מִמֶּךָּ״. וְאִי סָלְקָא דַעְתָּךְ בַּת נִישּׂוּאִין הֲוַאי, אֲחָתֵיהּ מִי הֲוָה שַׁרְיָא לֵיהּ? אֶלָּא שְׁמַע מִינַּהּ: בַּת יְפַת תּוֹאַר הָיְתָה.
human_translation: And Rav Yehuda says Rav says: Tamar was the daughter of a beautiful woman as it is stated: “Now, therefore, speak, please, to the king, for he will not withhold me from you” And if it enters your mind she was the daughter of married, would have permitted sister to him Rather, learn from she was the daughter of a beautiful woman
llm_translation: And Rav Yehudah said in the name of Rav: Tamar, the daughter of Yefet, was beautiful, as it is stated: "Now therefore speak to the king, for he will not withhold me from you." And if you were to suggest that she was a married woman, who would have permitted her? Rather, learn from it: Tamar, the daughter of Yefet, was beautiful.

hebrew_text: ״וּלְאַמְנוֹן רֵעַ וּשְׁמוֹ יוֹנָדָב בֶּן שִׁמְעָה אֲחִי דָוִד וְיוֹנָדָב אִישׁ חָכָם וְגוֹ׳״. אָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר רַב: אִישׁ חָכָם לְרִשְׁעָה.
human_translation: “And Amnon had a friend whose name was Jonadab, son of Shimeah, David’s brother, wise man” Rav Yehuda says Rav says: A wise man for wickedness.
llm_translation: "And Amnon had a friend, and his name was Jonadab son of Shimeah, David's brother. Now Jonadab was a very wise man." Rav Yehudah said in the name of Rav: "A wise man for evil."

hebrew_text: ״וַיֹּאמֶר ... מַדּוּעַ אַתָּה כָּכָה דַּל בֶּן הַמֶּלֶךְ ... וַיֹּאמֶר לוֹ יוֹנָדָב שְׁכַב עַל מִשְׁכָּבְךָ וְהִתְחָל וְגוֹ׳״, עַד ״וְעָשְׂתָה לְעֵינַי אֶת הַבִּרְיָה״. ״וַתִּקַּח הַמַּשְׂרֵת וַתִּצֹק לְפָנָיו״. אָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר רַב: שֶׁעָשְׂתָה לוֹ מִינֵי טִיגּוּן.
human_translation: “And he said to him: Why, son of the king, are you so, becoming leaner and Jonadab said to him: Lie on your bed and feign illness, and she should dress the food in my sight…And she took the pan and poured them out before him” Rav Yehuda says Rav says: that prepared kinds of fried [ tiggun ] for
llm_translation: "And he said ... 'Why are you so weak, O son of the king ...' And Jonadab said to him, 'Lie down on your bed and pretend,' etc." until "and 'you have done this thing before my eyes.'" "And the maid took and poured before him." Rav Yehudah said in the name of Rav: that she made for him various types of dainties."

hebrew_text: ״וַיִּשְׂנָאֶהָ אַמְנוֹן שִׂנְאָה גְּדוֹלָה מְאֹד״. מַאי טַעְמָא? אָמַר רַבִּי יִצְחָק: נִימָא נִקְשְׁרָה לוֹ וַעֲשָׂאַתּוּ כְּרוּת שׇׁפְכָה. וְכִי נִקְשְׁרָה לוֹ, אִיהִי מַאי עֲבַדָה? אֶלָּא אֵימָא: קָשְׁרָה לוֹ נִימָא וַעֲשָׂאַתּוּ כְּרוּת שׇׁפְכָה.
human_translation: “Then Amnon hated her with exceeding, great hatred, What is the reason Rabbi Yitzḥak says: a hair [ nima ] became tied his and caused him to be one whose penis has been severed. The Gemara asks: But if became tied his what did she do? Rather, say she tied a hair around his and she made him one whose penis has been severed
llm_translation: "And Amnon hated her with a very great hatred." What is the reason? Rabbi Yitzchak said: Let her be tied to him and let him make her like a woven sheet. And if she is tied to him, what can she do? Rather say: Let her be tied to him and let him make her like a woven sheet."

hebrew_text: אִינִי? וְהָא דָּרֵשׁ רָבָא: מַאי דִּכְתִיב ״וַיֵּצֵא לָךְ שֵׁם בַּגּוֹיִם בְּיׇפְיֵךְ״? שֶׁאֵין לָהֶן לִבְנוֹת יִשְׂרָאֵל לֹא שְׂעַר בֵּית הַשֶּׁחִי וְלָא בֵּית הָעֶרְוָה! שָׁאנֵי תָּמָר, דְּבַת יְפַת תּוֹאַר הֲוַאי.
human_translation: Is that so? But didn’t Rava interpret homiletically: What which is written: “And your renown went forth among the nations about your beauty” that Jewish women do not have armpit hair or pubic hair. Tamar is different, as she was the daughter of a beautiful woman,
llm_translation: I? But this that Rava expounded: What is the meaning of what is written, "And your name went forth among the nations for your beauty"? That the daughters of Israel do not have in them neither the hair of the pubic region nor the hair of the armpit! This is different with a date palm, for it is of beautiful appearance.

hebrew_text: ״וַתִּקַּח תָּמָר אֵפֶר עַל רֹאשָׁהּ וְאֶת כְּתֹנֶת הַפַּסִּים אֲשֶׁר עָלֶיהָ קָרָעָה״. תָּנָא מִשְּׁמֵיהּ דְּרַבִּי יְהוֹשֻׁעַ בֶּן קׇרְחָה: גָּדֵר גָּדוֹל גָּדְרָה תָּמָר בְּאוֹתָהּ שָׁעָה. אָמְרוּ: לִבְנוֹת מְלָכִים כָּךְ, לִבְנוֹת הֶדְיוֹטוֹת עַל אַחַת כַּמָּה וְכַמָּה. אִם לַצְּנוּעוֹת כָּךְ, לַפְּרוּצוֹת עַל אַחַת כַּמָּה וְכַמָּה. אָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר רַב: בְּאוֹתָהּ שָׁעָה גָּזְרוּ
human_translation: “And Tamar put ashes on her head and rent her garment of many colors that was on her” taught in the name of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Korḥa: Tamar established a great fence at that time said: such to the daughters of kings, all the more so to the daughters of ordinary such to modest women all the more so to licentious women. Rav Yehuda says Rav says: At that time they decreed
llm_translation: "And Tamar put ashes on her head and tore the long robe with sleeves that she was wearing." It was taught in the name of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Korcha: Tamar built a large fence at that moment. They said: To build kings like this, how much more so to build commoners all the more so. If for the modest ones like this, for the immodest all the more so. Rav Yehudah said in the name of Rav: At that moment they decreed.

hebrew_text: עַל הַיִּיחוּד, וְעַל הַפְּנוּיָה.
human_translation: about seclusion, and about a single woman.
llm_translation: On the yichud, and on the p'nuyah.

hebrew_text: יִחוּד? דְּאוֹרָיְיתָא הוּא! דְּאָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן יְהוֹצָדָק: רֶמֶז לְיִיחוּד מִן הַתּוֹרָה מִנַּיִין? שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״כִּי יְסִיתְךָ אָחִיךָ בֶן אִמֶּךָ״. וְכִי בֶּן אֵם מֵסִית, בֶּן אָב אֵינוֹ מֵסִית? אֶלָּא לוֹמַר לָךְ: בֵּן מִתְיַיחֵד עִם אִמּוֹ, וְאֵין אַחֵר מִתְיַיחֵד עִם כׇּל עֲרָיוֹת שֶׁבַּתּוֹרָה.
human_translation: Seclusion is by Torah As Rabbi Yoḥanan says in the name of Rabbi Shimon ben Yehotzadak: From where an allusion to seclusion by Torah As it is stated: “If your brother, the son of your mother, entices you” But does the son of a mother entice, and does the son of a father not entice? Rather, to tell you a son be secluded with his mother. But another may not be secluded with those with whom relations are forbidden by the Torah,
llm_translation: Unity? It is from the Torah! As Rabbi Yochanan said in the name of Rabbi Shimon ben Yehotzadak: How do we know that there is an allusion to unity in the Torah? Because it says, "If your brother, the son of your mother, entices you." Is it only the son of the mother who entices, and the son of the father does not entice? Rather, it is to tell you: a son who unites with his mother, and no one else unites with all the forbidden relationships in the Torah.

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא אֵימָא: גָּזְרוּ עַל יִיחוּד דִּפְנוּיָה.
human_translation: Rather, say they decreed against seclusion with a single woman,
llm_translation: Rather say: They decreed regarding the prohibition of seclusion.

hebrew_text: ״וַאֲדֹנִיָּה בֶן חַגִּית מִתְנַשֵּׂא לֵאמֹר אֲנִי אֶמְלֹךְ״. אָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר רַב: מְלַמֵּד שֶׁבִּיקֵּשׁ לְהוֹלְמוֹ, וְלֹא הוֹלַמְתּוֹ.
human_translation: “Now Adonijah, son of Haggith, exalted himself, saying: I will be king” Rav Yehuda says Rav says: teaches that he sought to fit him, but it did not fit him.
llm_translation: "And Adonijah the son of Haggith exalted himself, saying, 'I will be king.'" Rav Yehudah said in the name of Rav: This teaches that he sought to rebel, but he did not rebel.

hebrew_text: ״וַיַּעַשׂ לוֹ רֶכֶב וּפָרָשִׁים וַחֲמִשִּׁים אִישׁ רָצִים לְפָנָיו״. מַאי רְבוּתָא? אָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר רַב: כּוּלָּן נְטוּלֵי טְחוֹל וַחֲקוּקֵי כַּפּוֹת רַגְלַיִם הָיוּ.
human_translation: “And he prepared for himself chariots and riders and fifty people to run before him” What is the novelty Rav Yehuda says Rav says: all had spleens removed and had the soles of their feet hollowed,
llm_translation: "And he made for himself a chariot and horsemen, and fifty men running before him." What is the meaning of "revuta"? Rav Yehuda said in the name of Rav: All of them were wearing turbans and sandals with straps on their feet.

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ ״לֹא יַרְבֶּה לּוֹ סוּסִים״, אֶלָּא כְּדֵי מֶרְכַּבְתּוֹ. ״וְכֶסֶף וְזָהָב לֹא יַרְבֶּה לּוֹ מְאֹד״, אֶלָּא כְּדֵי לִיתֵּן אַפְסַנְיָא. וְכוֹתֵב לוֹ סֵפֶר תּוֹרָה לִשְׁמוֹ. יוֹצֵא לַמִּלְחָמָה – מוֹצִיאָהּ עִמּוֹ, נִכְנָס – הוּא מַכְנִיסָהּ עִמּוֹ, יוֹשֵׁב בַּדִּין – הִיא עִמּוֹ, מֵיסֵב – הִיא כְּנֶגְדּוֹ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְהָיְתָה עִמּוֹ וְקָרָא בוֹ כׇּל יְמֵי חַיָּיו״.
human_translation: “shall not accumulate many horses for himself” only for his chariot “Neither shall he greatly accumulate silver and gold for himself” only enough to provide soldiers’ sustenance [ aspanya ]. And writes himself a Torah scroll for his sake, he goes out to war, he brings it out with him. he comes in he brings it in with him. he sits in judgment, it is with him. he reclines it is opposite him, as it is stated: “And it shall be with him and he shall read it all the days of his life”
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: "He shall not multiply horses for himself," except for his chariot. "Nor shall he greatly increase silver and gold for himself," except to give a ransom. And he shall write for himself a Torah scroll. When he goes out to war, he takes it with him; when he enters, he brings it with him. When he sits in judgment, it is with him; when he eats, it is opposite him, as it is stated: "And it shall be with him, and he shall read from it all the days of his life."

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: ״לֹא יַרְבֶּה לוֹ סוּסִים״ – יָכוֹל אֲפִילּוּ כְּדֵי מֶרְכַּבְתּוֹ וּפָרָשָׁיו? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר ״לוֹ״ – לוֹ אֵינוֹ מַרְבֶּה, אֲבָל מַרְבֶּה הוּא כְּדֵי רִכְבּוֹ וּפָרָשָׁיו. הָא מָה אֲנִי מְקַיֵּים ״סוּסִים״? סוּסִים הַבַּטְלָנִין. מִנַּיִין שֶׁאֲפִילּוּ סוּס אֶחָד וְהוּא בָּטֵל שֶׁהוּא בְּ״לֹא יַרְבֶּה״? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר ״לְמַעַן הַרְבּוֹת סוּס״.
human_translation: The Sages taught “He shall not accumulate many horses [ susim ] for himself might even for his chariot and riders. the verse states: “For himself,” for himself, he shall not accumulate but he may accumulate for his chariot and riders. How, then, do I realize “horses [ susim ]” idle horses, From where that even one horse that is idle, that he “he shall not accumulate”? The verse states: “For the sake of accumulating horses [ sus ],”
llm_translation: The sages taught: "He shall not multiply horses" - Can he not even have enough for his chariot and his horsemen? The verse says "for him" - for him he shall not multiply, but he may multiply enough for his chariot and his horsemen. How do I fulfill "horses"? Idle horses. From where do we derive that even one horse, if it is idle, is included in "he shall not multiply"? The verse says "in order to multiply horses."

hebrew_text: וְכִי מֵאַחַר דַּאֲפִילּוּ סוּס אֶחָד וְהוּא בָּטֵל קָאֵי בְּ״לֹא יַרְבֶּה״, ״סוּסִים״ לְמָה לִי? לַעֲבוֹר בְּלֹא תַעֲשֶׂה עַל כׇּל סוּס וְסוּס.
human_translation: But once that even one horse that is idle stands “he shall not accumulate,” why do I “horses” to transgress prohibition for each and every horse.
llm_translation: And when since even one horse and it is idle stands in "not increase," "horses" for what to me? To transgress in "do not do" upon every horse and horse.

hebrew_text: טַעְמָא דִּכְתַב רַחֲמָנָא ״לוֹ״, הָא לָאו הָכִי הֲוָה אָמֵינָא אֲפִילּוּ כְּדֵי רִכְבּוֹ וּפָרָשָׁיו נָמֵי לָא? לָא צְרִיכָא, לְאַפּוֹשֵׁי.
human_translation: reason that the Merciful One writes: for himself,” consequently, not this, I would say even for his chariot and riders not No, necessary to add
llm_translation: Reason of that wrote the Merciful One "to him," this not so was I saying even as much as the time of his riding and his spreading also not? Not necessary, to exclude.

hebrew_text: ״וְכֶסֶף וְזָהָב לֹא יַרְבֶּה לוֹ״, אֶלָּא כְּדֵי לִיתֵּן אַפְסַנְיָא. תָּנוּ רַבָּנַן: ״וְכֶסֶף וְזָהָב לֹא יַרְבֶּה לוֹ״ – יָכוֹל אֲפִילּוּ כְּדֵי לִיתֵּן אַפְסַנְיָא? תַּלְמוּד לוֹמַר ״לוֹ״ – לוֹ אֵינוֹ מַרְבֶּה, אֲבָל מַרְבֶּה הוּא כְּדֵי לִיתֵּן אַפְסַנְיָא.
human_translation: “Neither shall he greatly accumulate silver and gold for himself” only enough to provide soldiers’ sustenance. The Sages taught “neither shall he greatly accumulate silver and gold for himself,” might even enough to provide soldiers’ sustenance. the verse states: “For himself,” for himself, he shall not accumulate but he may accumulate enough to provide soldiers’ sustenance.
llm_translation: Talmudic text: "And silver and gold he shall not multiply for himself," except to give a half-shekel. The Rabbis taught: "And silver and gold he shall not multiply for himself" – Could this even be for the purpose of giving a half-shekel? The verse teaches "for himself" – for himself he shall not multiply, but he may multiply in order to give a half-shekel.

hebrew_text: טַעְמָא דִּכְתַב רַחֲמָנָא ״לוֹ״? הָא לָאו הָכִי, הֲוָה אָמֵינָא: אֲפִילּוּ כְּדֵי לִיתֵּן אַפְסַנְיָא נָמֵי לָא? לָא צְרִיכָא, לְהַרְוָוחָה.
human_translation: reason that the Merciful One writes: for himself,” consequently, not this, I would say is not even enough to provide soldiers’ sustenance; No, necessary to a liberal appropriation
llm_translation: Reason for which wrote Merciful One "to him"? This not so, was saying: even to give a small needle not? Not necessary, for satisfaction.

hebrew_text: הַשְׁתָּא דְּאָמְרַתְּ ״לוֹ״ לִדְרָשָׁה, ״לֹא יַרְבֶּה לוֹ נָשִׁים״ מַאי דָּרְשַׁתְּ בֵּיהּ? לְמַעוֹטֵי הֶדְיוֹטוֹת.
human_translation: Now that you have said “for himself” for a derivation what do you derive from “He shall not add many wives for himself”? to exclude ordinary
llm_translation: The question that you asked, "to him" for interpretation, "he shall not multiply wives for himself," what did you interpret in it? To exclude commoners.

hebrew_text: רַב יְהוּדָה רָמֵי: כְּתִיב ״וַיְהִי לִשְׁלֹמֹה אַרְבָּעִים אֶלֶף אֻרְוֹת סוּסִים לְמֶרְכַּבְתּוֹ״, וּכְתִיב ״וַיְהִי לִשְׁלֹמֹה אַרְבַּעַת אֲלָפִים אֻרְווֹת סוּסִים״. הָא כֵּיצַד? אִם אַרְבָּעִים אֶלֶף אִיצְטַבְלָאוֹת הָיוּ, כׇּל אֶחָד וְאֶחָד הָיוּ בּוֹ אַרְבַּעַת אֲלָפִים אֻרְווֹת סוּסִים. וְאִם אַרְבַּעַת אֲלָפִים אִיצְטַבְלָאוֹת הָיוּ, כׇּל אֶחָד וְאֶחָד הָיוּ בּוֹ אַרְבָּעִים אֶלֶף אֻרְווֹת סוּסִים.
human_translation: Rav Yehuda raises a contradiction: It is written “And Solomon had forty thousand stalls of horses for his chariots” and it is written “And Solomon had four thousand stalls for horses How these If there were forty thousand large stables [ itztablaot ], each and every one had in it four thousand stalls, for horses. And if there were four thousand large stables, each and every one had in it forty thousand stalls for horses.
llm_translation: Rav Yehudah raises a contradiction: It is written, "And Solomon had forty thousand stalls of horses for his chariots," and it is also written, "And Solomon had four thousand stalls for horses." How is this possible? If there were forty thousand stalls, each one contained four thousand horses. And if there were four thousand stalls, each one contained forty thousand horses.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי יִצְחָק רָמֵי: כְּתִיב ״אֵין כֶּסֶף נֶחְשָׁב בִּימֵי שְׁלֹמֹה לִמְאוּמָה״, וּכְתִיב ״וַיִּתֵּן שְׁלֹמֹה אֶת הַכֶּסֶף בִּירוּשָׁלִַים כָּאֲבָנִים״? לָא קַשְׁיָא: כָּאן – קוֹדֶם שֶׁנָּשָׂא שְׁלֹמֹה אֶת בַּת פַּרְעֹה, כָּאן – לְאַחַר שֶׁנָּשָׂא שְׁלֹמֹה אֶת בַּת פַּרְעֹה.
human_translation: Rabbi Yitzḥak raises a contradiction: It is written “Silver was not worth anything in the days of Solomon” and it is written “And the king made silver in Jerusalem as stones” not difficult: Here, before Solomon married Pharaoh’s daughter. There, after Solomon married Pharaoh’s daughter.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yitzchak raises a contradiction: It is written, "Silver was not considered valuable in the days of Solomon to the extent of stones," and it is written, "And Solomon gave the silver in Jerusalem as stones." This is not difficult: here - before Solomon took the daughter of Pharaoh, here - after Solomon took the daughter of Pharaoh.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי יִצְחָק: בְּשָׁעָה שֶׁנָּשָׂא שְׁלֹמֹה אֶת בַּת פַּרְעֹה, יָרַד גַּבְרִיאֵל וְנָעַץ קָנֶה בַּיָּם, וְהֶעֱלָה שִׂירְטוֹן, וְעָלָיו נִבְנָה כְּרַךְ גָּדוֹל שֶׁבְּרוֹמִי.
human_translation: Rabbi Yitzḥak says: When Solomon married Pharaoh’s daughter, Gabriel descended and implanted a pole in the sea. And raised up a sandbar [ sirton ] and on it the great city of Rome was built.
llm_translation: Rabbi Yitzchak said: At the moment when Solomon married the daughter of Pharaoh, Gabriel descended and thrust a reed into the sea, and gathered a sandbank, upon which a great city was built in Rome.

hebrew_text: וְאָמַר רַבִּי יִצְחָק: מִפְּנֵי מָה לֹא נִתְגַּלּוּ טַעֲמֵי תּוֹרָה? שֶׁהֲרֵי שְׁתֵּי מִקְרָאוֹת נִתְגַּלּוּ טַעְמָן, וְנִכְשַׁל בָּהֶן גְּדוֹל הָעוֹלָם. כְּתִיב: ״לֹא יַרְבֶּה לוֹ נָשִׁים״. אָמַר שְׁלֹמֹה: ״אֲנִי אַרְבֶּה וְלֹא אָסוּר״. וּכְתִיב: ״וַיְהִי לְעֵת זִקְנַת שְׁלֹמֹה נָשָׁיו הִטּוּ אֶת לְבָבוֹ״.
human_translation: And Rabbi Yitzḥak says: For what were the rationales of Torah not revealed? because the rationales of two verses were revealed, the greatest in the world, failed in It is written “He shall not add many wives for himself, Solomon said: I will add many, but I will not turn away, And it is written: “For it came to pass, when Solomon was old, that his wives turned away his heart
llm_translation: And Rabbi Yitzchak said: Why were the reasons of the Torah not revealed? For behold, two verses revealed their reasons, and the great of the world stumbled in them. It is written: "He shall not multiply wives for himself." Solomon said: "I will multiply and it is not forbidden." And it is written: "And it came to pass, when Solomon was old, that his wives turned away his heart."

hebrew_text: וּכְתִיב: ״לֹא יַרְבֶּה לּוֹ סוּסִים״, וְאָמַר שְׁלֹמֹה: ״אֲנִי אַרְבֶּה וְלֹא אָשִׁיב״. וּכְתִיב: ״וַתֵּצֵא מֶרְכָּבָה מִמִּצְרַיִם בְּשֵׁשׁ וְגוֹ׳״.
human_translation: And it is written: he shall not accumulate many horses for himself and Solomon said: I will accumulate many, but I will not return. And it is written: “And a chariot and went out of Egypt for six
llm_translation: Talmudic text: And it is written: "He shall not multiply horses for himself," and Solomon said: "I will multiply, but not return." And it is written: "And the chariot came out of Egypt with six hundred chariots." English translation: And it is written: "He shall not multiply horses for himself," and Solomon said: "I will multiply, but not return." And it is written: "And the chariot came out of Egypt with six hundred chariots."

hebrew_text: וְכוֹתֵב סֵפֶר תּוֹרָה לִשְׁמוֹ. תְּנָא: וּבִלְבַד שֶׁלֹּא יִתְנָאֶה בְּשֶׁל אֲבוֹתָיו.
human_translation: writes a Torah scroll for his sake. taught provided that he does not beautify himself with of his ancestors
llm_translation: And writes a Torah scroll for his name. Tanna: And only if he does not make a vow regarding his ancestors.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רָבָא: אַף עַל פִּי שֶׁהִנִּיחוּ לוֹ אֲבוֹתָיו לְאָדָם סֵפֶר תּוֹרָה, מִצְוָה לִכְתּוֹב מִשֶּׁלּוֹ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְעַתָּה כִּתְבוּ לָכֶם אֶת הַשִּׁירָה״. אֵיתִיבֵיהּ אַבָּיֵי: וְכוֹתֵב לוֹ סֵפֶר תּוֹרָה לִשְׁמוֹ, שֶׁלֹּא יִתְנָאֶה בְּשֶׁל אֲחֵרִים. מֶלֶךְ – אִין, הֶדְיוֹט – לֹא!
human_translation: Rava says: even if a person’s ancestors left him a Torah scroll, a mitzva to write of one’s own, as it is stated: “Now, therefore, write for yourselves song Abaye raised an objection to him And he writes himself a Torah scroll for his sake, so that he does not beautify himself with of others. a king, yes, an ordinary not.
llm_translation: Rava said: Even though one's ancestors left him a Torah scroll, it is a commandment to write one for himself, as it is stated: "And now write for yourselves this song." Abaye raised an objection: And one writes a Torah scroll for himself, with his own name, so that he does not benefit from the Torah of others. A king - no, a commoner - no!

hebrew_text: לָא, צְרִיכָא לִשְׁתֵּי תּוֹרוֹת, וְכִדְתַנְיָא: ״וְכָתַב לוֹ אֶת מִשְׁנֵה וְגוֹ׳״ – כּוֹתֵב לִשְׁמוֹ שְׁתֵּי תּוֹרוֹת: אַחַת שֶׁהִיא יוֹצְאָה וְנִכְנֶסֶת עִמּוֹ, וְאַחַת שֶׁמּוּנַּחַת לוֹ בְּבֵית גְּנָזָיו.
human_translation: No, necessary two Torah And as it is taught “That he shall write for himself a second he writes for his sake two Torah one that goes out and comes in with him and one that is placed in his treasury.
llm_translation: The matter requires two Torahs, as it was taught: "And he shall write for himself a duplicate, etc." - he writes two Torahs for his name: one that goes out and comes in with him, and one that is stored in his treasury.

hebrew_text: אוֹתָהּ שֶׁיּוֹצְאָה וְנִכְנֶסֶת עִמּוֹ, עוֹשֶׂה אוֹתָהּ כְּמִין קָמֵיעַ וְתוֹלָהּ בִּזְרוֹעוֹ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״שִׁוִּיתִי ה׳ לְנֶגְדִּי תָמִיד כִּי מִימִינִי בַּל אֶמּוֹט״. אֵינוֹ נִכְנָס בָּהּ לֹא לְבֵית הַמֶּרְחָץ וְלֹא לְבֵית הַכִּסֵּא, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְהָיְתָה עִמּוֹ וְקָרָא בוֹ״ – מָקוֹם הָרָאוּי לִקְרוֹת בּוֹ.
human_translation: the one that goes out and comes in with him, he makes it like an amulet, and he hangs on his arm, as it is stated: “I have set the Lord always before me; He is at my right hand, that I shall not be moved” He does not go into the bathhouse with it, nor into the bathroom, as it is stated: “And it shall be with him and he shall read from it” a place that is appropriate for reading from it.
llm_translation: That which goes out and comes in with him, he makes it like a type of amulet and hangs it on his arm, as it is said: "I have set the Lord always before me; because He is at my right hand, I shall not be moved." It does not enter with him neither the bathroom nor the toilet, as it is said: "And it shall be with him, and he shall read it" - a place suitable for reading it.

hebrew_text: אָמַר מָר זוּטְרָא, וְאִיתֵּימָא מָר עוּקְבָא: בַּתְּחִלָּה נִיתְּנָה תּוֹרָה לְיִשְׂרָאֵל בִּכְתָב עִבְרִי וּלְשׁוֹן הַקּוֹדֶשׁ. חָזְרָה וְנִיתְּנָה לָהֶם בִּימֵי עֶזְרָא בִּכְתָב אַשּׁוּרִי וּלְשׁוֹן אֲרַמִּי. בֵּירְרוּ לָהֶן יִשְׂרָאֵל כְּתָב אַשּׁוּרִי וּלְשׁוֹן הַקּוֹדֶשׁ, וְהִנִּיחוּ לַהֶדְיוֹטוֹת כְּתָב עִבְרִית וּלְשׁוֹן אֲרַמִּי.
human_translation: Mar Zutra says, and some say Mar Ukva Initially, Torah was given to the Jewish people in Ivrit script, and the sacred tongue, It was given to them again in the days of Ezra in Ashurit script and Aramaic tongue. The Jewish people selected Ashurit script and the sacred tongue and left Ivrit script and Aramaic tongue for the commoners.
llm_translation: Master Zutra said, and some say it was Master Ukva: Initially, the Torah was given to the Israelites in Hebrew script and the holy language. It was then given to them in the days of Ezra in Assyrian script and Aramaic language. The Israelites chose for themselves Assyrian script and the holy language, and left for the common people Hebrew script and Aramaic language.

hebrew_text: מַאן הֶדְיוֹטוֹת? אָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: כּוּתָאֵי. מַאי כְּתָב עִבְרִית? אָמַר רַב חִסְדָּא: כְּתָב לִיבּוֹנָאָה.
human_translation: Who are commoners? Rav Ḥisda said: The Samaritans [ Kutim ]. What is Ivrit script? Rav Ḥisda says: Libona’a script.
llm_translation: Who are the laymen? Rav Ḥisdah said: The Samaritans. What is Hebrew script? Rav Ḥisdah said: The Libona script.

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא, רַבִּי יוֹסֵי אוֹמֵר: רָאוּי הָיָה עֶזְרָא שֶׁתִּינָּתֵן תּוֹרָה עַל יָדוֹ לְיִשְׂרָאֵל, אִילְמָלֵא לֹא קְדָמוֹ מֹשֶׁה. בְּמֹשֶׁה הוּא אוֹמֵר: ״וּמֹשֶׁה עָלָה אֶל הָאֱלֹהִים״, בְּעֶזְרָא הוּא אוֹמֵר: ״הוּא עֶזְרָא עָלָה מִבָּבֶל״. מָה עֲלִיָּיה הָאֲמוּרָה כָּאן – תּוֹרָה, אַף עֲלִיָּיה הָאֲמוּרָה לְהַלָּן – תּוֹרָה.
human_translation: It is taught Rabbi Yosei says: Ezra was suitable, for Torah to be given by him to the Jewish people, had Moses not come first With regard to Moses states: “And Moses went up to God” with regard to Ezra states: “This Ezra went up from Babylon Just as going up stated here, Torah, so too, going up stated there, Torah,
llm_translation: It was taught: Rabbi Yosei says: Ezra was worthy that the Torah should have been given through him to Israel, had it not already been preceded by Moses. Regarding Moses, it is said: "And Moses went up to God," and regarding Ezra, it is said: "This Ezra went up from Babylon." Just as the ascent mentioned here refers to the Torah, so too the ascent mentioned there refers to the Torah.

hebrew_text: בְּמֹשֶׁה הוּא אוֹמֵר: ״וְאֹתִי צִוָּה ה׳ בָּעֵת הַהִיא לְלַמֵּד אֶתְכֶם חֻקִּים וּמִשְׁפָּטִים״. בְּעֶזְרָא הוּא אוֹמֵר: ״כִּי עֶזְרָא הֵכִין לְבָבוֹ לִדְרֹשׁ אֶת תּוֹרַת ה׳ אֱלֹהָיו וְלַעֲשֹׂת וּלְלַמֵּד בְּיִשְׂרָאֵל חֹק וּמִשְׁפָּט״. וְאַף עַל פִּי שֶׁלֹּא נִיתְּנָה תּוֹרָה עַל יָדוֹ, נִשְׁתַּנָּה עַל יָדוֹ הַכְּתָב, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר:
human_translation: With regard to Moses states: “And the Lord commanded me at that time to teach you statutes and ordinances” with regard to Ezra states: “For Ezra had set his heart to seek the Torah of the Lord his God and to do it and to teach in Israel statutes and ordinances” And even though Torah was not given by him, the script was changed by him, as it is stated:
llm_translation: In Moses he says: "And I commanded you at that time statutes and ordinances." In Ezra he says: "For Ezra had set his heart to seek the law of the Lord, and to do and to teach in Israel statutes and ordinances." And even though the Torah was not given through him, the Scripture was changed through him, as it is said:

hebrew_text: ״וּכְתָב הַנִּשְׁתְּוָן כָּתוּב אֲרָמִית וּמְתֻרְגָּם אֲרַמִּית״. וּכְתִיב: ״לָא כָהֲלִין כְּתָבָא לְמִקְרֵא וּפִשְׁרֵהּ לְהוֹדָעָה לְמַלְכָּא״. [מְלַמֵּד שֶׁבְּאוֹתוֹ הַיּוֹם נִיתַּן] וּכְתִיב: ״וְכָתַב אֶת מִשְׁנֵה הַתּוֹרָה הַזֹּאת״ – כְּתָב הָרָאוּי לְהִשְׁתַּנּוֹת.
human_translation: “And the writing of the letter [ hannishtevan ] was written in the Aramaic script, and set forth in the Aramaic tongue” And it is written “Then came in all the king’s wise men. But they could not read the writing, nor make known to the king the interpretation” And it is written: “That he shall write for himself a second [ mishne ] Torah” a script that is apt to be changed [ lehishtannot ].
llm_translation: "And the prescription is written in Aramaic and translated into Aramaic." And it is written: "They did not write the document for reading and interpretation for the king." Teaching that on that day it was given And it is written: "And he shall write for himself this second law" - he should write in a manner suitable for alteration.

hebrew_text: לָמָּה נִקְרָא שְׁמוֹ אַשּׁוּרִי? שֶׁעָלָה עִמָּהֶם מֵאַשּׁוּר.
human_translation: Why called Ashurit ? Because it ascended with from Ashur
llm_translation: Why is his name called Assyrian? Because he came up with them from Assyria.

hebrew_text: תַּנְיָא, רַבִּי אוֹמֵר: בַּתְּחִלָּה בִּכְתָב זֶה נִיתְּנָה תּוֹרָה לְיִשְׂרָאֵל. כֵּיוָן שֶׁחָטְאוּ, נֶהְפַּךְ לָהֶן לְרוֹעֵץ. כֵּיוָן שֶׁחָזְרוּ בָּהֶן, הֶחְזִירוֹ לָהֶם, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״שׁוּבוּ לְבִצָּרוֹן אֲסִירֵי הַתִּקְוָה גַּם הַיּוֹם מַגִּיד מִשְׁנֶה אָשִׁיב לָךְ״.
human_translation: It is taught Rabbi says: Initially, the Torah was given to the Jewish people in this script, Once sinned, it turned into an impairment for them Once they repented, was returned to them, as it is stated: “Return to the stronghold, you prisoners of hope; even today do I declare that I will render double [ mishne ] unto you”
llm_translation: It was taught: Rabbi says: At first, this writing was given to Israel. Once they sinned, it turned into a poison for them. Once they repented, it was returned to them, as it is stated: "Return to the stronghold, you prisoners of hope; even today I declare that I will restore double to you."

hebrew_text: לָמָּה נִקְרָא שְׁמוֹ אַשּׁוּרִי? שֶׁמְּאוּשָּׁר בִּכְתָבו‍ֹ.
human_translation: why is it called Ashurit ? Because it is meusheret , in script.
llm_translation: Why is his name called Ashuri? Because he is fortunate in his writing.

hebrew_text: רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן בֶּן אֶלְעָזָר אוֹמֵר מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר בֶּן פַּרְטָא, שֶׁאָמַר מִשּׁוּם רַבִּי אֶלְעָזָר הַמּוֹדָעִי: כְּתָב זֶה לֹא נִשְׁתַּנָּה כׇּל עִיקָּר, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וָוֵי הָעַמּוּדִים״. מָה עַמּוּדִים לֹא נִשְׁתַּנּוּ, אַף וָוִים לֹא נִשְׁתַּנּוּ. וְאוֹמֵר: ״וְאֶל הַיְּהוּדִים כִּכְתָבָם וְכִלְשׁוֹנָם״ – מָה לְשׁוֹנָם לֹא נִשְׁתַּנָּה, אַף כְּתָבָם לֹא נִשְׁתַּנָּה.
human_translation: Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says in the name of Rabbi Eliezer ben Perata, who said in the name of Rabbi Elazar HaModa’i: This script did not change at all, as it is stated “The hooks of [ vavei ] the poles” just as the poles were not changed, so too, the hooks [ vavim ] were not changed. And states: “And to the Jews according to their script and according to their language” just as their language was not changed so too, their script was not changed.
llm_translation: Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says in the name of Rabbi Eliezer ben Parta, who said in the name of Rabbi Elazar HaModa'i: "This writing has not changed at all, as it is stated: 'Woe to the pillars.' Just as the pillars have not changed, so too the hooks have not changed." And he says: "And to the Jews according to their writing and according to their language" - just as their language has not changed, so too their writing has not changed.

hebrew_text: אֶלָּא מָה אֲנִי מְקַיֵּים ״אֶת מִשְׁנֵה הַתּוֹרָה הַזֹּאת״? לִשְׁתֵּי תּוֹרוֹת: אַחַת שֶׁיּוֹצְאָה וְנִכְנֶסֶת עִמּוֹ, וְאַחַת שֶׁמּוּנַּחַת לוֹ בְּבֵית גְּנָזָיו. אוֹתָהּ שֶׁיּוֹצְאָה וְנִכְנֶסֶת עִמּוֹ – עוֹשֶׂה אוֹתָהּ כְּמִין קָמֵיעַ וְתוֹלָהּ בִּזְרוֹעוֹ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״שִׁוִּיתִי ה׳ לְנֶגְדִּי תָּמִיד״.
human_translation: But how do I realize “a second [ mishne ] Torah” to two Torah scrolls one that goes out and comes in with him, and one that is placed in his treasury. the one that goes out and comes in with him, he makes it like an amulet, and he hangs on his arm. As it is stated “I have set the Lord always before me;
llm_translation: Rather, how do I fulfill "this repetition of the Torah"? For two Torahs: one that goes out and comes in with him, and one that is stored in his treasury. That one that goes out and comes in with him - he should make it like a kind of amulet and hang it on his arm, as it is said: "I have set the Lord always before me."

hebrew_text: וְאִידַּךְ, הַאי ״שִׁוִּיתִי״ מַאי דָּרֵישׁ בֵּיהּ? הָהוּא מִיבְּעֵי לֵיהּ כִּדְרַב חָנָה בַּר בִּיזְנָא, דְּאָמַר רַב חָנָה בַּר בִּיזְנָא אָמַר רַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן חֲסִידָא: הַמִּתְפַּלֵּל צָרִיךְ שֶׁיִּרְאֶה עַצְמוֹ כְּאִילּוּ שְׁכִינָה כְּנֶגְדּוֹ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״שִׁוִּיתִי ה׳ לְנֶגְדִּי תָמִיד״.
human_translation: And the other what does he expound from that “I have set” He requires that in accordance with of Rav Ḥana bar Bizna, as Rav Ḥana bar Bizna says Rabbi Shimon Ḥasida says: One who prays needs to see himself as if the Divine Presence is opposite him, as it is stated: “I have set the Lord always before me”
llm_translation: And the other, this "I have set" what does it expound? That one requires it as Rav Ḥanah bar Bizna said, as Rav Ḥanah bar Bizna said in the name of Rabbi Shimon Ḥasida: One who prays should consider himself as if the Divine Presence is opposite him, as it is stated: "I have set the Lord before me always."

hebrew_text: לְרַבִּי שִׁמְעוֹן, דְּאָמַר: ״כְּתָב זֶה לֹא נִשְׁתַּנָּה״, מַאי ״לָא כָהֲלִין כְּתָבָא לְמִקְרֵא״? אָמַר רַב: בְּגִימַטְרִיָּא אִיכְּתִיב לְהוֹן ״יטת יטת אדך פוגחמט״.
human_translation: According to Rabbi Shimon, who says this script was not changed what “they could not read the writing” Rav says: it was written for them in gimatriyya . Yod , tet , tav ; yod , tet , tav ; alef , yod , dalet , khaf ; peh , vav , gimmel , ḥet , mem , tet .
llm_translation: To Rabbi Shimon, who said: "This writing has not changed," what is meant by "the letters of the writing do not resemble the letters of the Scripture"? Rav said: Through gematria, it is written to them, "Yitah Yitah Adach Pogachmat."

hebrew_text: מַאי פָּרֵישׁ לְהוּ? ״מְנֵא מְנֵא תְּקֵל וּפַרְסִין״. ״מְנֵא״ – מְנָא אֱלָהָא מַלְכוּתָךְ וְהַשְׁלְמַהּ לָךְ. ״תְּקֵל״ – תְּקִילְתָּא בְמֹאזַנְיָא וְהִשְׁתְּכַחַתְּ חַסִּיר. ״פַּרְסִין״ – פְּרִיסַת מַלְכוּתָךְ וִיהִיבַת לְמָדַי וּפָרָס.
human_translation: What did explain to them? “ Mene mene tekel ufarsin ” “ Mene ”: God has numbered [ mena ] your kingdom and brought it to an end. “ Tekel ”: You are weighed [ tekilta ] on the scale and are found lacking. “ Parsin ”: Your kingdom is divided [ perisat ] and given to the Medes and Persians”
llm_translation: "What did he explain to them? 'Mene, Mene, Tekel, Upharsin.' 'Mene' - God has numbered the days of your kingdom and brought it to an end. 'Tekel' - you have been weighed on the scales and found wanting. 'Upharsin' - your kingdom is divided and given to the Medes and Persians."

hebrew_text: וּשְׁמוּאֵל אָמַר: ״ממתוס ננקפי אאלרן״. וְרַבִּי יוֹחָנָן אָמַר: ״אנם אנם לקת ניסרפו״. רַב אָשֵׁי אָמַר: ״נמא נמא קתל פורסין״.
human_translation: And Shmuel says: “ Mamtos nankafei a’alran .” And Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Anem anem leket nisrapu . Rav Ashi says: Nema nema ketal pursin .
llm_translation: Samuel said: "From Matos we are pierced, O Elran." And Rabbi Yochanan said: "Anam anam, to the thornbush they were burned." Rav Ashi said: "Nema nema, the Persians killed."

hebrew_text: מַתְנִי׳ אֵין רוֹכְבִין עַל סוּסוֹ, וְאֵין יוֹשְׁבִין עַל כִּסְאוֹ, וְאֵין מִשְׁתַּמְּשִׁין בְּשַׁרְבִיטוֹ, וְאֵין רוֹאִין אוֹתוֹ כְּשֶׁהוּא מִסְתַּפֵּר, וְלֹא כְּשֶׁהוּא עָרוֹם, וְלֹא כְּשֶׁהוּא בְּבֵית הַמֶּרְחָץ, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״שׂוֹם תָּשִׂים עָלֶיךָ מֶלֶךְ״, שֶׁתְּהֵא אֵימָתוֹ עָלֶיךָ.
human_translation: One may not ride on horse, and one may not sit on his throne, and one may not use his scepter, and one may not see him when he is having his hair cut, nor when he is naked, nor when he is in the bathhouse, as it is stated: “You shall set a king over you” that his fear should be upon you.
llm_translation: The Mishnah teaches: One may not ride on his horse, nor sit on his chair, nor use his scepter, nor look at him when he is relieving himself, neither when he is naked, nor when he is in the bathhouse, as it is stated: "You shall surely set a king over you" (Deuteronomy 17:15), that his fear shall be upon you.

hebrew_text: גְּמָ׳ אָמַר רַב יַעֲקֹב אָמַר רַבִּי יוֹחָנָן: אֲבִישַׁג מוּתֶּרֶת לִשְׁלֹמֹה, וַאֲסוּרָה לַאֲדֹנִיָּה. מוּתֶּרֶת לִשְׁלֹמֹה – דְּמֶלֶךְ הָיָה, וּמֶלֶךְ מִשְׁתַּמֵּשׁ בְּשַׁרְבִיטוֹ שֶׁל מֶלֶךְ. וַאֲסוּרָה לַאֲדֹנִיָּה – דְּהֶדְיוֹט הוּא.
human_translation: Rav Ya’akov says Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Abishag permitted to Solomon but forbidden to Adonijah, permitted to Solomon, as he was a king, and a king may use the scepter of a king. forbidden to Adonijah, as he an ordinary
llm_translation: Talmudic text: Gemara, Rav Yaakov said in the name of Rabbi Yochanan: Avishag was permitted for Shlomo, and forbidden for Adoniyahu. Permitted for Shlomo - because he was a king, and a king makes use of the staff of another king. And forbidden for Adoniyahu - because he was a commoner.

hebrew_text: אֲבִישַׁג מַאי הִיא? דִּכְתִיב: ״וְהַמֶּלֶךְ דָּוִד זָקֵן בָּא בַּיָּמִים וְגוֹ׳ וַיֹּאמְרוּ לוֹ עֲבָדָיו יְבַקְשׁוּ וְגוֹ׳״, וּכְתִיב: ״וַיְבַקְשׁוּ נַעֲרָה יָפָה וְגוֹ׳״, וּכְתִיב: ״וְהַנַּעֲרָה יָפָה עַד מְאֹד וַתְּהִי לַמֶּלֶךְ סֹכֶנֶת וַתְּשָׁרְתֵהוּ״. אֲמַרָה: ״נִינְסְבַן!״ אֲמַר לַהּ: ״אֲסִירַתְּ לִי״.
human_translation: Abishag, what is it? As it is written: “Now King David was old and stricken in years…and his servants said to him, let there be sought and it is written: “So they sought for a beautiful maiden… and it is written: “And the maiden was very beautiful and she became a companion to the king and ministered to him, said Marry me. said to her: You are forbidden to me,
llm_translation: Avishag, what is it? As it is written: "Now King David was old, advanced in years, and they said to him, 'Let them seek for my lord the king a young virgin,'" and it is written: "Let them seek for a fair damsel," and it is written: "And the damsel was very fair, and she became the king's attendant and served him." She said: "We are married!" He said to her: "You are forbidden to me."

hebrew_text: אֲמַרָה לֵיהּ: חַסְּרֵיהּ לְגַנָּבָא, נַפְשֵׁיהּ בְּשַׁלְמָנָא נָקֵיט. אֲמַר לְהוּ: קִרְאוּ לִי לְבַת שֶׁבַע. וּכְתִיב: ״וַתָּבֹא בַת שֶׁבַע אֶל הַמֶּלֶךְ הַחַדְרָה״. אָמַר רַב יְהוּדָה אָמַר רַב: בְּאוֹתָהּ שָׁעָה קִינְּחָה בַּת שֶׁבַע בִּשְׁלֹשׁ עֶשְׂרֵה מַפּוֹת.
human_translation: said to him: When the thief is lacking he makes himself like a man of peace. said to Call Bathsheba to me. And it is written: “And Bathsheba went in to the king into the chamber; Rav Yehuda says Rav says: At that time, Bathsheba wiped with thirteen cloths,
llm_translation: He said to him: "His lack to the thief, his soul he took with a peace offering." He said to them: "Call me Bathsheba." And it is written: "And Bathsheba came to the king into the chamber." Rav Yehudah said in the name of Rav: At that moment, Bathsheba winked with thirteen winks.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַב שֶׁמֶן בַּר אַבָּא: בֹּא וּרְאֵה כַּמָּה קָשִׁין גֵּירוּשִׁין, שֶׁהֲרֵי דָּוִד הַמֶּלֶךְ הִתִּירוּ לוֹ לְיַיחֵד, וְלֹא הִתִּירוּ לוֹ לְגָרֵשׁ.
human_translation: Rav Shemen bar Abba says: Come and see how severe divorce as they permitted for King David to be secluded but they did not permitted for him to divorce
llm_translation: Rav Shemen bar Abba said: Come and see how difficult divorces are, for behold, King David was permitted to marry multiple wives, but they did not permit him to divorce.

hebrew_text: אָמַר רַבִּי אֱלִיעֶזֶר: כׇּל הַמְגָרֵשׁ אֶת אִשְׁתּוֹ רִאשׁוֹנָה, אֲפִילּוּ מִזְבֵּחַ מוֹרִיד עָלָיו דְּמָעוֹת, שֶׁנֶּאֱמַר: ״וְזֹאת שֵׁנִית תַּעֲשׂוּ כַּסּוֹת דִּמְעָה אֶת מִזְבַּח ה׳ בְּכִי וַאֲנָקָה מֵאֵין עוֹד פְּנוֹת אֶל הַמִּנְחָה וְלָקַחַת רָצוֹן מִיֶּדְכֶם״, וּכְתִיב: ״וַאֲמַרְתֶּם עַל מָה עַל כִּי ה׳ הֵעִיד בֵּינְךָ וּבֵין אֵשֶׁת נְעוּרֶיךָ אֲשֶׁר אַתָּה בָּגַדְתָּה בָּהּ וְהִיא חֲבֶרְתְּךָ וְאֵשֶׁת בְּרִיתֶךָ״.
human_translation: Rabbi Eliezer says: anyone who divorces his first wife, even the altar sheds tears about him, as it is stated: “And further, this you should do: Cover the altar of the Lord with tears, with weeping and sighing, from His no longer showing regard to the offering, nor receiving it with goodwill from your hand” and it is written: “Yet you say: Why?
